text: The effect ultimately that we've seen from a human capital point of view is displacement. We have more people now than we've ever had, but the nature of the work that they do is more strategic. It's more about modeling, validation, asking the right questions, being focused around creative levers. And less so the like trench work of implementation and bid modifiers at the keyword level on Google search, and some of the really hardcore manual analysis we had to do.
speaker: Jonathan Becker
context: Lenny asks Jonathan about how AI is impacting the performance marketing industry. Jonathan explains that AI has been influencing their industry for over a decade, as platforms like Google and Facebook have used AI to automate many manual tasks. He describes how this automation has changed the nature of work at his agency, shifting employees from manual implementation work to more strategic responsibilities.
text_ko: 인적 자본(human capital) 관점에서 보면 결국 나타난 효과는 역할의 재배치(displacement)이에요. 지금 인원은 예전보다 더 많지만, 하는 일의 성격이 훨씬 더 전략적이에요. 이제는 모델링(modeling)과 검증(validation), 올바른 질문을 던지는 것, 창의적 레버(creative levers)에 집중하는 비중이 커졌어요. 반면 구글 검색의 키워드 수준에서 입찰 조정(bid modifiers)을 일일이 손보는 일이나, 예전처럼 정말 수작업 분석(manual analysis)을 해야 했던 그런 실무 중심의 작업은 줄었어요.
text_zh: 从人力资源的角度来看，我们看到的最终效果其实是人员转型。现在我们的人比以前还多，但是他们干的活儿性质变了，更偏战略性了。更多的是做建模、验证，问对问题，专注在创意杠杆(creative levers)上。不像以前那样做苦力活儿，比如在谷歌搜索里调关键词的出价修饰符(bid modifiers)，还有那些特别费劲的手工分析工作。
text_es: Al final, lo que hemos visto desde el punto de vista del capital humano es un desplazamiento. Tenemos más gente ahora que nunca, pero el tipo de trabajo que hacen es más estratégico. Se trata más de modelado, validación, hacer las preguntas correctas, enfocarse en palancas creativas (creative levers). Y menos del trabajo pesado de implementación y modificadores de pujas (bid modifiers) a nivel de palabra clave en Google search, y algunos de los análisis manuales súper técnicos que teníamos que hacer antes.

text: On our creative group, we can come up with mockups, in literally, 1% of the time that it took. And so you still have to understand what questions to ask of the AI and be capable of iterating, but these rough drafts that you might show the artwork of to a client to say, 'Do we like this more or do we like this more?' That's AI generated. It's really interesting.
speaker: Jonathan Becker
context: Jonathan continues explaining how AI tools are transforming creative work at his performance marketing agency. He describes how AI image generators like Dall-E and MidJourney allow his creative team to produce initial mockups and concept artwork dramatically faster than before. However, he emphasizes that human expertise is still needed to ask the right questions and iterate on the AI-generated outputs.
text_ko: 우리 크리에이티브 팀에서는 예전에 걸리던 시간의 문자 그대로 1% 만에 목업(mockups)을 만들어낼 수 있어요. 물론 인공지능(AI)에게 어떤 질문을 해야 할지 이해하고, 반복(iterate)해서 다듬을 수 있어야 해요. 그래도 클라이언트에게 '이게 더 나아요, 아니면 이게 더 나아요?' 하면서 아트워크(artwork) 초안(rough drafts)을 보여줄 수 있을 정도의 안들이 인공지능(AI)으로 생성된다는 건 정말 흥미로워요.
text_zh: 我们创意团队现在做原型(mockup)的速度，真的是比以前快了一百倍。当然你还是得知道怎么问AI问题，怎么不断调整，但是那些给客户看的初稿啊、设计图什么的，就是问他们"你觉得这个好还是那个好？"这些都是AI生成的。真的挺有意思的。
text_es: En nuestro equipo creativo, podemos crear bocetos (mockups) en literalmente el 1% del tiempo que nos tomaba antes. O sea, todavía tienes que saber qué preguntas hacerle a la IA y ser capaz de iterar, pero esos borradores que le podrías enseñar a un cliente para decirle '¿Te gusta más esto o te gusta más esto otro?' Eso lo genera la IA. Está súper interesante.

text: I always say to people that the first rule of performance marketing is not to forget about offline marketing and the classic marketing that works for organizations. In other words, direct mail can really work, email marketing works beautifully, SEO can really work. There's all of these wonderful things at your disposal. The real crash and burn scenarios that I've seen are these, not fly by night brands, but brands that figured out... Just like with Uber, I figured out this weird tie-in where I could make free money from their referral system.
speaker: Jonathan Becker
context: Lenny asks about the perception that paid growth can become addictive like a drug for companies. Jonathan addresses this concern by explaining his philosophy of marketing channel diversification. He warns against putting all marketing budget into a single performance marketing channel, comparing it to investing all your money in one stock. He emphasizes the importance of maintaining a mix of both online and offline marketing channels to avoid volatility.
text_ko: 저는 항상 사람들에게 성과 마케팅의 첫 번째 규칙은 오프라인 마케팅과 조직에 효과적인 클래식 마케팅을 잊지 않는 것이라고 말해요. 다시 말해, 다이렉트 메일(direct mail)도 정말 효과적일 수 있고, 이메일 마케팅(email marketing)도 아주 잘 작동해요. SEO도 정말 효과적이에요. 여러분이 활용할 수 있는 멋진 것들이 많아요. 제가 본 진짜 실패 사례는 단기 브랜드가 아니라, 우버(Uber)처럼 그들의 추천 시스템을 통해 무료로 돈을 벌 수 있는 기회를 찾아낸 브랜드들이에요.
text_zh: 我经常跟别人说，效果营销(performance marketing)的第一条铁律就是别忘了线下营销和那些对公司确实管用的传统营销手段。换句话说，直邮真的有效果，邮件营销效果特别好，SEO也确实能起作用。你手头有这么多好用的工具。我见过的那些真正翻车的案例是这样的，不是那些三天打鱼两天晒网的品牌，而是那些琢磨出了门道的品牌...就像Uber一样，我发现了一个奇怪的套路，可以从他们的推荐系统(referral system)里白赚钱。
text_es: Siempre les digo a la gente que la primera regla del marketing de resultados (performance marketing) es no olvidarse del marketing offline y del marketing clásico que funciona para las organizaciones. O sea, el correo directo puede funcionar de maravilla, el email marketing funciona bárbaro, el SEO puede dar muy buenos resultados. Tienes todas estas herramientas increíbles a tu disposición. Los verdaderos fracasos que he visto son estos: no marcas que aparecen de la noche a la mañana, sino marcas que descubrieron... Igual que con Uber, yo descubrí esta conexión rara donde podía generar dinero gratis con su sistema de referidos.

text: Sometimes people find shortcuts, hacks if you will, to scale rapidly because of one specific nuance of the Facebook ad platform, or something like that. And what they fail to see is that those loopholes come and go. And so if they scale massively and their entire business is predicated on the performance of this one loophole that they found, or investing everything in a single channel, and then the conditions change, they're not going to be very happy and the business will suffer dramatically.
speaker: Jonathan Becker
context: Jonathan continues his explanation about why over-reliance on performance marketing can be dangerous. He describes how some companies discover temporary advantages or 'loopholes' in advertising platforms that allow them to scale quickly and cheaply. However, he warns that these advantages are typically short-lived, and companies that build their entire business model around exploiting one specific platform feature will face serious problems when those conditions change.
text_ko: 사람들이 가끔 페이스북 광고 플랫폼(Facebook ad platform)의 어떤 사소한 특징 때문에 빠르게 확장할 수 있는 쇼트컷(shortcuts)이나 핵(hacks)을 찾아내요. 그런데 사람들이 놓치는 건 그런 허점(loopholes)이 언제든 생겼다 사라질 수 있다는 점이에요. 그래서 그 허점 하나의 퍼포먼스(performance)에 비즈니스 전체를 걸거나 한 채널(channel)에 모든 걸 투자해 대규모로 확장하면, 상황이 바뀔 때 엄청난 타격을 받고 비즈니스가 크게 흔들려요.
text_zh: 有时候大家会找到一些捷径，或者说是窍门吧，比如利用Facebook广告平台的某个特殊机制来快速做大规模。但他们没看到的是，这些漏洞都是来来去去的。如果他们疯狂扩张，整个生意都建立在发现的这一个漏洞上，或者把所有鸡蛋都放在一个渠道里，等到情况一变，他们就傻眼了，生意也会遭受重创。
text_es: A veces la gente encuentra atajos, trucos si quieres, para crecer rápidamente por algún detalle específico de la plataforma de anuncios de Facebook, o algo así. Y lo que no logran ver es que esas lagunas van y vienen. Entonces, si escalan masivamente y todo su negocio depende del rendimiento de esta laguna que encontraron, o si invierten todo en un solo canal, y luego las condiciones cambian, no van a estar nada contentos y el negocio va a sufrir tremendamente.

text: The antidote to that is to have resources dedicated to paid and essentially iterate upon the creative assets themselves based on the data that we see coming from ad sets and campaigns in various channels. And so what that means is that you have to experiment. You have to take a bit of a scientific approach, although it's a bit of an art and a bit of a science. You have to try and isolate variables, maintain similar conditions across targeting, and then determine which style and feature of an ad performs best at which stage of the funnel versus which audience.
speaker: Jonathan Becker
context: Lenny asks Jonathan about the importance of creative testing in performance marketing. Jonathan explains that one major problem he sees is when brand teams create generic assets without understanding how paid channels work. He describes the solution: having dedicated resources for paid marketing that can systematically test and iterate on creative assets based on performance data, treating it as both an art and science.
text_ko: 그에 대한 해결책은 유료 마케팅에 전담 자원(인력·예산)을 배정해서, 여러 채널(channels)의 광고 세트(ad sets)와 캠페인(campaigns)에서 나오는 데이터를 바탕으로 크리에이티브 자산(creative assets)을 직접 지속적으로 테스트하고 개선하는 거예요. 즉, 실험을 해야 한다는 뜻이에요. 어느 정도는 예술적인 감각도 필요하지만 과학적인 접근법도 취해야 해요. 변수(variables)를 분리해 가면서 실험하고, 타깃팅(targeting)별로 조건을 비슷하게 유지한 뒤, 어떤 광고의 스타일이나 요소가 퍼널(funnel)의 어느 단계에서 어떤 오디언스(audience)에 대해 가장 잘 작동하는지 판단해야 해요.
text_zh: 解决这个问题的办法就是专门投入资源做付费推广，然后根据各个渠道的广告组合和推广活动(campaigns)反馈回来的数据，不断优化创意素材本身。这就意味着你得做各种测试，要用比较科学的方法来做，当然这个事儿既是门艺术也是门科学。你需要试着控制变量，在定向投放(targeting)上保持相似的条件，然后搞清楚哪种广告风格和特点在转化漏斗(funnel)的不同阶段、针对不同受众群体表现最好。
text_es: La solución es tener recursos dedicados a publicidad pagada y básicamente ir iterando los creativos basándote en los datos que ves de los conjuntos de anuncios (ad sets) y campañas en los diferentes canales. Esto significa que tienes que experimentar. Tienes que adoptar un enfoque medio científico, aunque también es un arte - tienes que tratar de aislar variables, mantener condiciones similares en la segmentación (targeting), y después determinar qué estilo y características de un anuncio funcionan mejor en cada etapa del embudo (funnel) según la audiencia.

text: We had plenty of projects that we worked on that flatlined during that period. And so the sense that there was a period of time where this was easy or it worked on any project is not correct in my opinion. With that said, we see companies that are spending millions of dollars a month on performance marketing channels like Google and Meta still, despite all the ups and downs that they have faced and they do so profitably.
speaker: Jonathan Becker
context: Lenny asks whether startups can still scale almost exclusively through performance marketing, referencing successful companies from the 2010s. Jonathan provides a balanced perspective, explaining that while successful unicorns did use performance marketing, not every company that used performance marketing succeeded. He clarifies that there was never a time when performance marketing was universally easy or guaranteed to work, even during the supposed 'golden era' of the 2010s.
vocabulary_highlights: despite all the ups and downs
text_ko: 그 기간 동안 우리가 진행하던 프로젝트 중 상당수가 성과가 정체되거나 중단됐어요. 그래서 이게 쉬웠다거나 어떤 프로젝트에나 통했다는 인식은 제 생각에 옳지 않아요. 그렇긴 해도 구글과 메타 같은 퍼포먼스 마케팅(performance marketing) 채널에 월 수백만 달러를 여전히 지출하면서 여러 기복을 겪었음에도 불구하고 수익을 내는 회사들을 보고 있어요.
text_zh: 我们在那段时间有很多项目都没什么起色，基本上是停滞不前的状态。所以如果有人觉得那段时间很轻松，或者觉得随便做个项目都能成功，我觉得这种想法是不对的。话虽如此，我们确实看到有些公司尽管经历了各种起起伏伏，但每个月还是会在Google、Meta这些效果营销(performance marketing)渠道上砸几百万美金，而且还能赚钱。
text_es: Tuvimos un montón de proyectos en los que trabajamos que se quedaron planos durante esa época. Entonces la idea de que hubo un período donde esto era fácil o funcionaba con cualquier proyecto no es correcta desde mi punto de vista. Dicho esto, seguimos viendo empresas que están gastando millones de dólares al mes en canales de marketing de performance como Google y Meta, a pesar de todas las subidas y bajadas que han enfrentado, y lo hacen de manera rentable.
